In class Exercise 10

Author

Hao Xian

Published

March 20, 2023

Modified

March 20, 2023

1 Loading the packages

pacman::p_load(tmap, SpatialAcc, sf, 
               ggstatsplot, reshape2, fca,
               tidyverse)
Note

For fca, there are some changes, in which it is opposite of the package use.

2 Reading the Data

2.1 Importing the Data

mpsz <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_NO_SEA_PL")
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_NO_SEA_PL' from data source 
  `/Users/school/Documents/GitHub/Week1/lessons/In-class/in-class_ex10/data/geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'

Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21

We would also need to import the geospatial datac for the hexagons as well and the point data from Eldercare data point as well.

hexagons <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "hexagons")

Once again, we can check the CRS information as well.

mpsz <- st_transform(mpsz, 3414)
eldercare <- st_transform(eldercare, 3414)
hexagons <- st_transform(hexagons, 3414)

We can once again verify the values as well.

2.2 Cleaning the Redunctant Data

There a number of reduntant data from the eldercare dataset and hexagons data set.

eldercare <- eldercare %>%
  select(fid, ADDRESSPOS) %>%
  rename(destination_id = fid,
         postal_code = ADDRESSPOS) %>%
  mutate(capacity = 100)

hexagons <- hexagons %>%
  select(fid) %>%
  rename(origin_id = fid) %>%
  mutate(demand = 100)

Notice that for the purpose of this hands-on exercise, a constant value of 100 is used. In practice, actual demand of the hexagon and capacity of the eldercare centre should be used.

2.3 Importing Aspatial Dataset

We will now be importing the Aspatial Dataset

ODMatrix <- read_csv("data/aspatial/OD_Matrix.csv", skip = 0)

We will need to transform the data into a thin format

distmat <- ODMatrix %>%
  select(origin_id, destination_id, total_cost) %>%
  spread(destination_id, total_cost)%>%
  select(c(-c('origin_id')))

we will need to convert it to kilometer

distmat_km <- as.matrix(distmat/1000)

3 Computing Distance Matrix (Optional)

eldercare_coord <- st_coordinates(eldercare)
hexagon_coord <- st_coordinates(hexagons)

There are many functions with the name distance, so we specify that it is from the Spatial Acc package

EucMatrix <- SpatialAcc::distance(hexagon_coord,
                                  eldercare_coord,
                                  type = 'euclidean')
EucMatrix_km <- as.matrix(EucMatrix/1000)

4 Modeling and Visualizing Accessibility (Hansen)

4.1 Computing Hansen’s Asscessibility

acc_Hansen <- data.frame(ac(hexagons$demand,
                            eldercare$capacity,
                            distmat_km, 
                            #d0 = 50,
                            power = 2, 
                            family = "Hansen"))

Since the displayed data is messy, we will just rename it.

colnames(acc_Hansen) <- "accHansen"

We will then convert the acc_Hansen to a tibble dataframe before merging it with the Hexagon data.

acc_Hansen <- as_tibble(acc_Hansen)
hexagon_Hansen <- bind_cols(hexagons, acc_Hansen)

4.2 Visualising Hansen

We can view the extend of the hexagons with the following

mapex <- st_bbox(hexagons)

We can use the data to form a high quality map as well.

tmap_mode("plot")
tm_shape(hexagon_Hansen,
         bbox = mapex) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accHansen",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(eldercare) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to eldercare: Hansen method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)

4.3 Statistical Graphic Visualisation

hexagon_Hansen <- st_join(hexagon_Hansen, mpsz, 
                          join = st_intersects)
ggplot(data=hexagon_Hansen, 
       aes(y = log(accHansen), ## we need to log,m otherwise we will not see anythong
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary", 
             fun.y="mean", 
             colour ="red", 
             size=2)

5 Modelling and Visualising Accessibility (KD2SFCA)

5.1 Computing KD2SFCA

The code is largely the same as the computation of Hansen with the exception of the Family being KD2sFCA

acc_KD2SFCA <- data.frame(ac(hexagons$demand,
                            eldercare$capacity,
                            distmat_km, 
                            d0 = 50,
                            power = 2, 
                            family = "KD2SFCA"))

colnames(acc_KD2SFCA) <- "accKD2SFCA"
acc_KD2SFCA <- as_tibble(acc_KD2SFCA)
hexagon_KD2SFCA <- bind_cols(hexagons, acc_KD2SFCA)

5.2 Visualizing KS2SFCA

Note that Mapex can be reused, as the based data is still the same.

tmap_mode("plot")
tm_shape(hexagon_KD2SFCA,
         bbox = mapex) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accKD2SFCA",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(eldercare) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to eldercare: KD2SFCA method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)

5.3 Statistical Graphical Visualization

hexagon_KD2SFCA <- st_join(hexagon_KD2SFCA, mpsz, 
                          join = st_intersects)

ggplot(data=hexagon_KD2SFCA, 
       aes(y = log(accKD2SFCA), 
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary", 
             fun.y="mean", 
             colour ="red", 
             size=2)

6 Modelling and Visualising Accessibility (SAM)

6.1 Computing SAM

The code is largely the same as the computation of Hansen with the exception of the Family being SAM

acc_SAM <- data.frame(ac(hexagons$demand,
                         eldercare$capacity,
                         distmat_km, 
                         d0 = 50,
                         power = 2, 
                         family = "SAM"))

colnames(acc_SAM) <- "accSAM"
acc_SAM <- as_tibble(acc_SAM)
hexagon_SAM <- bind_cols(hexagons, acc_SAM)

6.2 Visualizing SAM

Note that Mapex can be reused, as the based data is still the same.

tmap_mode("plot")
tm_shape(hexagon_SAM,
         bbox = mapex) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accSAM",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(eldercare) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to eldercare: SAM method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 3),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)

6.3 Statistical Graphical Visualization

hexagon_SAM <- st_join(hexagon_SAM, mpsz, 
                       join = st_intersects)

ggplot(data=hexagon_SAM, 
       aes(y = log(accSAM), 
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary", 
             fun.y="mean", 
             colour ="red", 
             size=2)
